title: 113_s2176
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commonsense Reporting Act of 2014". Congress acknowledges the need for reporting requirements under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act to balance law enforcement and individual privacy. Protection of insured individuals and minimizing the transmission of social security numbers is a priority. Collaboration between various departments is essential for streamlining reporting and administrative processes. To streamline reporting and administrative processes under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, agencies and departments should collaborate to minimize compliance burdens on businesses, insurance carriers, and individuals. SEC. 3. PROTECTION OF DEPENDENT PRIVACY. Amends section 6055(b) of the Internal Revenue Code to allow substitution of name and date of birth for TINs of dependents. Effective after December 31, 2013. SEC. 4. EMPLOYEE OPT-OUT. An individual's consent to receive tax statements electronically is deemed if they have previously consented to receive such statements in electronic form. This applies to both general tax statements and statements relating to health insurance coverage. The amendments made by this section apply to statements due after December 31, 2013, requiring consent to receive private health information electronically. SEC. 5. STUDY. The Department of the Treasury, in consultation with other departments, must report to Congress within 90 days on developing a prospective reporting system for employer compliance with health coverage information. The report should address processes for Exchanges to access this information for eligibility determinations. The Department of the Treasury must report to Congress on verifying eligibility for premium tax credits and cost-sharing subsidies under the Affordable Care Act, guidance for employers on reporting requirements, and barriers in data systems hindering development. The Internal Revenue Service must report to Congress on barriers to developing a verification system, statutory barriers to implementing a voluntary reporting system, and the costs of developing such a system. After the report is submitted, there will be a 60-day open comment period for employers and interested parties to respond. All comments will be publicly accessible.
